docs.lead_paragraph: The British drug maker AstraZeneca has settled in principle nearly all of the American product liability lawsuits over Seroquel, its blockbuster antipsychotic drug, the company said in a quarterly earnings report on Thursday.
docs.abstract: The company reported that it has paid out $647 million in litigation over the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: NO MORE MONEY The rumors have swirled for months now: would SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen, left, that has $14 billion in assets under management, actually refuse to take new money from investors? Turns out, the answer is yes. Even as SAC weathers regulatory scrutiny over suspicious trading in the last few years, Mr. Cohen has decided to shut the firm's flagship hedge fund to new investors in August, according to a person familiar with the firm. AZAM AHMED
docs.abstract: DealBook Online; hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is closed to new investors; Banco Santander reports first-half profit of 3.5 billion euros ($5 billion), down 21 percent from year-ago half; US appeals court in District of Columbia strikes down Securities and Exchange Commission's proxy access rule; Blackstone Group is in discussions to buy Emdeoon; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In Friday’s Fixes column, I wrote about the Medicines Patent Pool, a new organization trying to make AIDS drugs better, cheaper and available sooner to people who need them in poor countries.   It relies on voluntary donations of rights by patent holders, most of them pharmaceutical companies.   Its success is crucial;  new research shows that if we can dramatically increase the number of people on antiretroviral medicines, we can not only save millions of lives, but potentially cause the epidemic to die away.

headline.main: A Trade Barrier to Defeating AIDS
